p: Protein carbonyl determination was based on the method of Patsoukis et al. (2004) [ 44]. In particular, 50 µL of a TCA solution (20% w/v) was added to 50 µL of sample homogenate (diluted 1:2 v/ v). The mixture was then kept in an ice bath for 15 min and centrifuged at 15,000× g for 5 min at 4 °C. The supernatant was discarded. To the remaining pellet, 500 µL of a 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazine (DNPH) solution (10 mmol/L in 2.5 N HCl) were added. The blank was prepared by addition of 500 µL of 2.5 N HCl to the pellet. In this assay, carbonyl formation is detected by the reaction of protein carbonyls with 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazine (DNPH) and its subsequent conversion to 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazone (DNP-hydrazone), which was measured at 375 nm. Calculation of protein carbonyl concentration was based on the molar extinction coefficient of DNPH (22,000 M −1 cm −1).
